report.system_prompt: You are disk_agent. Do not produce PDDL or planning code. Keep the output structured and unambiguous so an orchestrator can parse it.
report.prompt: Provide a compact structured description of the six disks A..F including their ordering from smallest to largest and the initial and goal membership of each peg. Return only a machine-friendly summary (for example: objects and membership lists).

Do not emit PDDL; return a clear representation the orchestrator can use to synthesize the domain and problem.
report.prompt: Provide a compact summary that lists the pegs, the movement rules (one disk at a time, no larger on smaller), and a recommended set of predicates (for example: on, clear, disk, peg, smaller-than) and types to represent the state. Output should be machine-friendly and unambiguous.

pddl.system_prompt: You are the orchestrator. Integrate the structured summaries from disk_agent and peg_agent and produce a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem suitable for solving with the FastDownwards planner. The PDDL must model three pegs (left, middle, right), six disks A..F with correct size ordering, legal moves that move one disk at a time and forbid placing a larger disk on a smaller disk, the given initial state, and the specified goal state. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Target FastDownwards compatibility (use STRIPS-style constructs and explicit typing if helpful). Keep agent actions distinct if modelling multiple agent actors is relevant, but the main requirement is a correct single-agent planning encoding for FastDownwards that solves the instance.
pddl.prompt: You will receive the disk and peg reports. Combine them into a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem for the 6-disk Tower of Hanoi that FastDownwards can solve. Enclose the domain in <domain></domain> and the problem in <problem></problem>. Ensure object names, predicates, initial state and goal are consistent with the reports.
